intro: Lagarinthus interruptus, commonly known as the Florida rainflower, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its showy, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in moist, sandy soils and thrives in wetland environments. It has lance-shaped leaves and produces small, cylindrical fruits that contain numerous seeds. Due to its habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and endangered species in its native range.
